user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of irq:
```c
static int irq(void)
{
	int rc = 0;
	char *err_msg="";
	enum metal_log_level mll= metal_get_log_level();
	int i, tst_irq[2];

	/* Do not show LOG_ERROR or LOG_DEBUG for expected fail case */
	metal_set_log_level(METAL_LOG_CRITICAL);

	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		/* we only want to test the lib API, so create 'virtual' IRQs */
		tst_irq[i] = eventfd(0,0);
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
			  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
	}

	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[1], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 1 fail drv_id 1\n";
		goto out;
	}

	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	rc = metal_irq_register(tst_irq[0], irq_handler, (void *)1);
	if (rc) {
		err_msg = "register irq 0 after unregistering failed\n";
		goto out;
	}
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[0]);
	metal_irq_unregister(tst_irq[1]);

out:
	for (i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
		close(tst_irq[i]);
	}
	metal_set_log_level(mll);
	if ((err_msg[0] != '\0') && (!rc))
		rc = -EINVAL;
	if (rc) metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s", err_msg);
	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "%s: irq %d associated with fd %d\n",
		  __func__, i, tst_irq[i]);
explanation: Fragments not listed do not involve non-const-qualified pointer-to-object usage or are not pointer declarations/assignments and therefore are not relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Examples: tst_irq is an int array and eventfd/close operate on file descriptors (integers), local scalars (rc, i, mll) and enum usage are not pointer-to-object cases, the for-loop and goto control flow do not introduce pointer constness issues, and calls to metal_set_log_level/metal_irq_unregister do not take or produce non-const object pointers in the shown code. The handler identifier (irq_handler) and other function calls not expanded here either represent function pointers or external APIs whose signatures would need separate review; only the explicit pointer usages present in the shown code are reported above for investigation.
